title: Mexican government releases video of botched raid to capture El Chapo's son
text:
The Mexican government has released footage of the disastrous raid to capture Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman's son, which ended with 19 soldiers and police officers injured, and Ovidio Guzman eventually released by the armed forces.

The scenes from October 17 show heavily-armed soldiers at Guzman's door, asking him to come out with his hands up. A woman is the first to leave, and is told repeatedly by the soldiers to be calm. She protests that there are children inside.

Then the young cartel leader, believed to be around 27 years old, comes out of the house and is searched by police.

He is handed a phone and asked to call off the violence which is happening all around the house in the city of Culiacan, Sinaloa state. He refuses to help calm the chaos.

Outside the house, cartel members were waging war on the city - freeing prisoners from a city prison, setting vehicles on fire and launching an all-out assault using trucks mounted with machine guns.

Cartel members burned buses to demand Ovidio Guzman be released Credit: Jesus Bustamante/Reuters More

Mexican government forces battled the cartel members for hours, with eight killed - five of them cartel members.

Nine soldiers and two officials were taken hostage, and 16 police or military vehicles, and even one state aircraft, were hit by bullets.

One grisly image shown by the government on Wednesday appears to show a soldier lying in the rear of a truck, the bottom part of his leg blown off by a .50 caliber weapon.

Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, Mexico's president, made the decision to call off the raid and release Guzman. He has been strongly criticised for giving in to the cartel, but has insisted that Guzman's capture was not worth more than saving lives.

A bullet-ridden car on the streets of Culiacan after the October 17 fiasco Credit: Rashide Frias/AFP More

On Wednesday morning he looked on as Mexico's security minister, Alfonso Durazo, explained their actions.

“What could have become a scene of war and the shedding of innocent blood was resolved in favour of a return to peace and protecting the population,” he said.

Ovidio’s father led the powerful Sinaloa Cartel for decades, escaping from prison twice before being arrested and extradited to the US.

He was found guilty in a New York court in February of smuggling tons of drugs, and was sentenced to life in prison.

US authorities were also seeking the younger Guzman's extradition, on an arrest warrant issued in February.
